transcript:
Therapist: You've made some great insights today, Marcus. I'm impressed by your willingness to challenge your thoughts and try new strategies for setting boundaries. How are you feeling about our session today?

Patient: I'm feeling pretty good. It's been helpful to talk through some of these challenges and come up with a plan for moving forward. I know it won't be easy, but I feel more equipped to handle it now.

Therapist: That's great to hear! Remember, change takes time, and there will be ups and downs along the way. The important thing is to keep practicing and be kind to yourself in the process.

Patient: I'll definitely keep that in mind. It's easy for me to get discouraged when things don't go perfectly, but I'm trying to focus on progress, not perfection.

Therapist: That's a fantastic attitude to have! Progress is what matters, and every small step counts. Speaking of progress, let's talk about some homework for this week. We've covered a lot of ground today, so I want to make sure we prioritize what will be most helpful for you.

Patient: Sounds good. What do you suggest?

Therapist: First, I'd like you to continue practicing the boundary-setting language we discussed today. Try to identify at least one situation this week where you can assert your needs in a healthy way, and use the language we practiced. It might feel uncomfortable at first, but that's okay. The more you practice, the easier it will get.

Patient: Okay, I can do that. I have a feeling I'll have plenty of opportunities to practice at work this week.

Therapist: That's a great place to start! And remember, you can always modify the language to fit the situation and your comfort level. The goal is to communicate your needs clearly and kindly, not to be perfect.

Patient: Got it. What else?

Therapist: I'd also like you to continue working on challenging your negative thoughts, especially around setting boundaries. Use the thought record we practiced today to identify the evidence for and against your thoughts, and come up with alternative thoughts that are more balanced and helpful.

Patient: I will. I'm actually looking forward to seeing how that goes.

Therapist: That's great! And finally, I'd like you to start a positive data log, like we discussed earlier. Try to write down at least one positive experience, accomplishment, or moment of joy each day, no matter how small. This will help you start to shift your focus away from the negative and onto the positive.

Patient: I like that idea. It'll be nice to have a record of the good things, even on the tough days.

Therapist: Exactly! And we can review your positive data log together in our next session and celebrate your wins, big and small.

Patient: Sounds good. I'm looking forward to it.

Therapist: Me too! Remember, if you have any questions or concerns during the week, don't hesitate to reach out. I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate all your help and guidance.

Therapist: You're very welcome, Marcus. I'm honored to be a part of your journey. Take care, and I'll see you next week!

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed and practiced boundary-setting language and strategies
  - Challenged negative thoughts related to setting boundaries using thought records
  - Introduced the concept of a positive data log to track positive experiences and accomplishments

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (ongoing from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion practice (ongoing from previous sessions)
  - Boundary-setting language and practice (new)
  - Positive data log (new)

- Homework assigned:
  - Practice boundary-setting language in at least one situation this week
  - Continue using thought records to challenge negative thoughts related to setting boundaries
  - Start a positive data log and record at least one positive experience, accomplishment, or moment of joy each day

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Patient reported some ups and downs in mood since the last session, with good days and bad days
  - Identified challenges with setting boundaries at work and in social situations
  - Depression symptoms continue to include negative self-talk, feelings of overwhelm, and difficulty getting out of bed on some days
  - Patient showed insight and motivation to practice new skills and challenge negative thoughts

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I need to be available and accommodating at all times, or people will think I'm lazy or selfish"
  - Intermediate belief: "If I set boundaries, I'll miss out on opportunities and damage my relationships"

- Important information to carry forward to future sessions:
  - Continue monitoring patient's progress with boundary-setting and thought records
  - Review positive data log and celebrate wins in the next session
  - Explore any new challenges or insights that come up in the week ahead

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review patient's experience with homework assignments, including boundary-setting practice, thought records, and positive data log
  - Discuss any challenges or questions that came up while practicing new skills
  - Continue exploring beliefs about setting boundaries and self-worth, and introduce additional techniques for challenging these beliefs as appropriate
  - Check in on patient's overall mood and any changes in depression symptoms
